articles.headline: U.S. Weighs Takeover of Two Mortgage Giants
articles.snippet: Under the plan, shares of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac would be worth little or nothing, and any losses on mortgages they own or guarantee would be paid by taxpayers.
articles.abstract: Under the plan, shares of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac would be worth little or nothing, and any losses on mortgages they own or guarantee would be paid by taxpayers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Alarmed by the growing financial stress at the nation’s two largest mortgage finance companies, senior Bush administration officials are considering a plan to have the government take over one or both of the companies and place them in a conservatorship if their problems worsen, people briefed about the plan said on Thursday.
articles.byline: By Stephen Labaton and Steven R. Weisman

articles.headline: Deal for Anheuser-Busch Is Said to Be Near
articles.snippet: The possible deal would create the world’s largest brewer.
articles.abstract: The possible deal would create the world’s largest brewer.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a reversal of its previous hostility to the idea, Anheuser-Busch is in active talks to sell itself to the Belgian brewer InBev in a friendly deal, people briefed on the matter said Thursday night.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: An Interpreter Speaking Up for Migrants
articles.snippet: A professor broke the code of confidentiality among legal interpreters to criticize the arrest of illegal immigrants.
articles.abstract: A professor broke the code of confidentiality among legal interpreters to criticize the arrest of illegal immigrants.
articles.lead_paragraph: WATERLOO, Iowa — In 23 years as a certified Spanish interpreter for federal courts, Erik Camayd-Freixas has spoken up in criminal trials many times, but the words he uttered were rarely his own.

articles.headline: Serenity Prayer Stirs Up Doubt: Who Wrote It?
articles.snippet: The prayer is about to endure a controversy over its authorship that is likely to be anything but serene.
articles.abstract: The prayer is about to endure a controversy over its authorship that is likely to be anything but serene.
articles.lead_paragraph: Generations of recovering alcoholics, soldiers, weary parents, exploited workers and just about anybody feeling beaten down by life have found solace in a short prayer that begins, “God grant me the serenity to accept the things I cannot change.”

articles.headline: Toyota Scales Back Production of Big Vehicles
articles.snippet: Toyota acknowledged that, like its rival automakers in Detroit, it misjudged the drastic swing in the American market away from larger vehicles.
articles.abstract: Toyota acknowledged that, like its rival automakers in Detroit, it misjudged the drastic swing in the American market away from larger vehicles.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Toyota acknowledged Thursday that, like its rival automakers in Detroit, it misjudged the drastic swing in the American market away from larger vehicles.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: Loan-Agency Woes Swell From a Trickle to a Torrent
articles.snippet: The rapid erosion of investors’ confidence has become a crisis for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the two main backers of mortgage financing.
articles.abstract: The rapid erosion of investors’ confidence has become a crisis for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the two main backers of mortgage financing.
articles.lead_paragraph: The word began spreading across Wall Street trading desks on Monday morning: Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the giant companies at the heart of the nation’s housing market, might be in trouble.

articles.headline: For Short Sellers, It Doesn’t Get Much Better
articles.snippet: As shareholders of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac watched their investments plunge in value, short sellers, who bet against stocks, could count their winnings.
articles.abstract: As shareholders of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac watched their investments plunge in value, short sellers, who bet against stocks, could count their winnings.
articles.lead_paragraph: Blood is in the water, and short sellers, often viewed as the sharks of Wall Street, are circling.
